docs.title: 🎲 Probability Calculator
docs.text:
Welcome to the Probability Calculator documentation.

This project provides an easy-to-use Python module for simulating the probability of drawing specific combinations of colored balls from a hat. It uses Monte‑Carlo simulation to estimate probabilities empirically.

docs.title: 🚀 Features
docs.text:
• 🎩 Hat class to hold colored balls
  • 🔀 Random draws without replacement
  • 📊 Monte‑Carlo probability estimation
  • 🧪 Fully customizable experiments
  • 🖥️ Command Line Interface included
  • 📚 Complete documentation and examples

docs.title: 📦 Installation
docs.text: pip install .

docs.title: 📘 What You Can Do
docs.text:
• Simulate drawing balls from a hat
  • Estimate probability of pulling certain colors
  • Run thousands of experiments automatically
  • Use from Python or from the command line

docs.title: 🧩 API Reference
docs.text: This page provides detailed documentation for all public interfaces in the Probability Calculator package.

docs.title: 🎩 Hat Class
docs.text: A container that stores colored balls and allows random draws without replacement.

docs.title: 📌 Constructor
docs.text: Hat(**kwargs)

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• Each keyword argument represents a color and the associated number of balls.

Example:

hat = Hat(red=3, blue=2)

docs.title: 🔽 draw(num_balls)
docs.text: Draws a number of balls at random without replacement.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: • num_balls (int) — number of balls to draw.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: A list of strings representing the drawn balls.

docs.title: Behavior
docs.text:
• If num_balls ≥ total balls, all balls are returned.
  • Otherwise, a random subset is returned.

Example:

hat.draw(4)

docs.title: 🧵 __repr__()
docs.text:
Provides a developer-friendly string representation:

Hat(['red', 'blue', 'green'])

docs.title: 🧪 experiment() Function
docs.text: Runs repeated Monte-Carlo trials to estimate the probability of drawing a specific combination of balls.

docs.title: 📌 Signature
docs.text: experiment(hat, expected_balls, num_balls_drawn, num_experiments)

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Type Description hat Hat The original hat object (deep copied internally) expected_balls dict[str, int] Required colors and their minimum counts num_balls_drawn int Number of balls drawn per experiment num_experiments int Number of Monte-Carlo repetitions

docs.title: 🔄 Process
docs.text:
1. Deep copy the hat
  2. Draw num_balls_drawn balls
  3. Count colors
  4. Check if all expected colors meet/exceed their required counts
  5. Repeat for num_experiments trials
  6. Return successes / num_experiments

docs.title: 📤 Returns
docs.text:
A float between 0 and 1, the estimated probability.

Example:

from probability_calculator import Hat, experiment

hat = Hat(black=6, red=4, green=3)

probability = experiment(
    hat,
    expected_balls={"red": 2, "green": 1},
    num_balls_drawn=5,
    num_experiments=3000
)

print(probability)

docs.title: 🧭 Notes
docs.text:
• The original hat is not modified
  • More experiments → more accurate results
  • Uses random sampling without replacement

Proceed to Examples to see full workflows in action! 🚀

docs.title: 🖥️ Command Line Interface (CLI)
docs.text: The Probability Calculator provides a convenient command-line interface that allows you to run Monte‑Carlo probability simulations without writing Python code.

docs.title: ▶️ Running the CLI
docs.text:
Once installed (pip install .), run:

probability-calculator --help

This displays available commands and options.

docs.title: 🎩 Creating a Hat via CLI
docs.text:
You specify balls using color=count pairs:

probability-calculator --hat red=3 blue=2 green=6

This defines a hat with:

  • 3 red balls
  • 2 blue balls
  • 6 green balls

docs.title: 🔢 Setting Expected Outcome
docs.text:
Specify the expected minimum number of balls of each color:

--expect red=2 green=1

docs.title: 🎲 Running a Full Simulation
docs.text:
Example:

probability-calculator \
  --hat red=3 blue=2 green=6 \
  --expect red=2 green=1 \
  --draw 5 \
  --experiments 2000

Output:

Estimated Probability: 0.2385

docs.title: 📌 CLI Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description --hat Define hat contents as color=count pairs --expect Required ball counts for success --draw Number of balls drawn per experiment --experiments Number of Monte‑Carlo repetitions

docs.title: 🧠 How It Works
docs.text:
1. Parse colors and counts from CLI
  2. Construct a Hat object
  3. Perform repeated draws
  4. Calculate how many experiments meet expectations
  5. Print probability estimate

docs.title: 📘 Examples
docs.text: This page provides complete examples demonstrating how to use the Probability Calculator for simulations and probability estimation.

docs.title: 🎩 Example 1 — Create a Hat and Draw Balls
docs.text:
from probability_calculator import Hat

hat = Hat(red=3, blue=2, green=6)

print("Initial contents:", hat.contents)
drawn = hat.draw(4)

print("Drawn balls:", drawn)
print("Remaining:", hat.contents)

Example output:

Initial contents: ['red', 'red', 'red', 'blue', 'blue', 'green', 'green', 'green', 'green', 'green', 'green']
Drawn balls: ['green', 'red', 'green', 'blue']
Remaining: ['red', 'red', 'blue', 'green', 'green', 'green', 'green']

docs.title: 🧪 Example 2 — Run a Probability Experiment
docs.text:
from probability_calculator import Hat, experiment

hat = Hat(red=3, blue=2, green=6)

prob = experiment(
    hat=hat,
    expected_balls={"red": 2, "green": 1},
    num_balls_drawn=5,
    num_experiments=2000
)

print("Estimated probability:", prob)

Example output:

Estimated probability: 0.2385

docs.title: 🔄 Example 3 — Use Random Seed for Reproducibility
docs.text:
import random
from probability_calculator import Hat, experiment

random.seed(42)

hat = Hat(yellow=5, blue=4, red=3)

prob = experiment(
    hat,
    expected_balls={"yellow": 2, "blue": 1},
    num_balls_drawn=4,
    num_experiments=500
)

print(prob)

docs.title: 🎯 Example 4 — CLI Usage (Command Line)
docs.text:
After installation (pip install .), run:

probability-calculator --hat red=3 blue=2 green=6 --expect red=2 green=1 --draw 5 --experiments 2000

Example output:

Estimated Probability: 0.2385

docs.title: 📊 Example 5 — Large Simulation
docs.text:
from probability_calculator import Hat, experiment

hat = Hat(red=8, blue=5, green=7, yellow=10)

prob = experiment(
    hat,
    expected_balls={"yellow": 3, "red": 2},
    num_balls_drawn=6,
    num_experiments=10000
)

print("Probability:", prob)

Explore more by checking the Usage Guide or API Reference. Happy simulating! 🎲

docs.title: 📘 Usage Guide
docs.text: This guide explains how to use the Probability Calculator to simulate drawing colored balls from a hat and estimate probabilities using Monte‑Carlo experiments.

docs.title: 🎩 Creating a Hat
docs.text:
Create a hat by specifying colors and counts:

from probability_calculator import Hat

hat = Hat(red=3, blue=2, green=6)
print(hat.contents)
# ['red', 'red', 'red', 'blue', 'blue', 'green', 'green', 'green', 'green', 'green', 'green']

Each keyword argument becomes that many balls inside the hat.

docs.title: 🔀 Drawing Balls
docs.text:
Draw a specific number of balls without replacement:

drawn = hat.draw(4)
print(drawn)
# Example: ['green', 'red', 'blue', 'green']

If you try to draw more balls than the hat contains:

hat.draw(50)

It simply returns all remaining balls.

docs.title: 🧪 Running Experiments
docs.text:
Use the experiment() function to run repeated Monte‑Carlo trials.

from probability_calculator import experiment, Hat

hat = Hat(red=3, blue=2, green=6)

prob = experiment(
    hat=hat,
    expected_balls={"red": 2, "green": 1},
    num_balls_drawn=5,
    num_experiments=2000,
)

print(prob)  # Example: 0.2385

docs.title: 📌 Parameters
docs.text: Parameter Type Description hat Hat Original hat instance expected_balls dict Required colors + counts num_balls_drawn int Balls to draw each experiment num_experiments int Monte‑Carlo repetitions

docs.title: 📈 Interpreting Results
docs.text:
The returned value is a probability estimate between 0 and 1:

  • 0.0 → expected balls almost never appear
  • 1.0 → expected balls almost always appear
  • Between → approximate likelihood from repeated trials

More experiments = higher accuracy:

experiment(..., num_experiments=10000)

docs.title: 🧹 Important Notes
docs.text:
• The original hat is not modified — deep copies are used internally.
  • Drawing is always random and without replacement.
  • More balls drawn → greater variance in outcomes.
  • For deterministic testing, seed the RNG:
import random
random.seed(42)

Next, visit the API Reference or explore Examples for complete workflows.
